required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Memantine Versus Placebo on Ischemic Stroke Outcome

brief_summary.textblock: The researchers aim to investigate the effect of memantine on stroke outcome in a randomized double-blind placebo-controlled clinical trial.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Investigation of Neurological Deficit by National Institute of Health Scale Score (NIHSS)
primary_outcome.description: The National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale, or NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) is a tool used by healthcare providers to objectively quantify the impairment caused by a stroke. The NIHSS is composed of 11 items, each of which scores a specific ability between a 0 and 4. For each item, a score of 0 typically indicates normal function in that specific ability, while a higher score is indicative of some level of impairment. The individual scores from each item are summed in order to calculate a patient's total NIHSS score. The maximum possible score is 42, with the minimum score being a 0. Higher score is indicative of some level of impairment in neurological function.

primary_outcome.measure: Investigation of Disability by Modified Rankin Scale (mRS)
primary_outcome.description: The modified Rankin Scale (mRS) is a commonly used scale for measuring the degree of disability or dependence in the daily activities of people who have suffered a stroke or other causes of neurological disability. The scale runs from 0-6, running from perfect health without symptoms to death. 0 - No symptoms. - No significant disability. Able to carry out all usual activities, despite some symptoms. - Slight disability. Able to look after own affairs without assistance, but unable to carry out all previous activities. - Moderate disability. Requires some help, but able to walk unassisted. - Moderately severe disability. Unable to attend to own bodily needs without assistance, and unable to walk unassisted. - Severe disability. Requires constant nursing care and attention, bedridden, incontinent. - Dead.

secondary_outcome.measure: Investigation of Neurological Deficit by National Institute of Health Scale Score (NIHSS)
secondary_outcome.description: The National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale, or NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) is a tool used by healthcare providers to objectively quantify the impairment caused by a stroke. The NIHSS is composed of 11 items, each of which scores a specific ability between a 0 and 4. For each item, a score of 0 typically indicates normal function in that specific ability, while a higher score is indicative of some level of impairment. The individual scores from each item are summed in order to calculate a patient's total NIHSS score. The maximum possible score is 42, with the minimum score being a 0. Higher score is indicative of some level of impairment in neurological function.

secondary_outcome.measure: Investigation of Disability by Modified Rankin Scale (mRS)
secondary_outcome.description: The modified Rankin Scale (mRS) is a commonly used scale for measuring the degree of disability or dependence in the daily activities of people who have suffered a stroke or other causes of neurological disability. The scale runs from 0-6, running from perfect health without symptoms to death. 0 - No symptoms. - No significant disability. Able to carry out all usual activities, despite some symptoms. - Slight disability. Able to look after own affairs without assistance, but unable to carry out all previous activities. - Moderate disability. Requires some help, but able to walk unassisted. - Moderately severe disability. Unable to attend to own bodily needs without assistance, and unable to walk unassisted. - Severe disability. Requires constant nursing care and attention, bedridden, incontinent. - Dead.

arm_group.description: Patients with ischemic stroke in middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory who will receive 20 mg/d(2 tab 5mg BID) memantine for 7 days and then 10mg/d(1 tab 5mg BID) memantine for 21 days.
Patients with ischemic stroke in middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory who will receive placebo(2 tab BID) for 7 days and continue placebo(1 tab BID) for 21 days.

intervention.description: Beside the usual treatment of ischemic stroke, this group will receive placebo for 4 weeks.
Beside the usual treatment for ischemic stroke this group will be treated by memantine.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Presentation at first 24hrs of disease onset
- Confirmation of ischemic stroke in MCA territory by imaging.
- Accepted consent form
Exclusion Criteria:
- Allergy history to memantine
- Stage 4 -5 renal failure base on Acute Kidney Injury Network criteria
- Moderate to severe hepatic failure (Child-Pugh criteria, grade B and C)
- History of epilepsy
- History of dementia
- History of memantine use in recent 6 months
- Pregnancy or breastfeeding
- Severe drug adverse effects

group.title: Memantine
group.description: Patients with ischemic stroke in middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory who will receive 20 mg/d(2 tab 5mg BID) memantine for 7 days and then 10mg/d(1 tab 5mg BID) memantine for 21 days. Memantine: Beside the usual treatment for ischemic stroke this group will be treated by memantine.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Patients with ischemic stroke in middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory who will receive placebo(2 tab BID) for 7 days and continue placebo(1 tab BID) for 21 days. Placebo: Beside the usual treatment of ischemic stroke, this group will receive placebo for 4 weeks.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
